awd_titl_txt: AF:  Small:  Theory and Applications of Untrusted Quantum Devices
awd_abstract_narration:
Imagine that you would like to make use of the powerful information processing capability of quantum devices but you are not yet equipped to implement the necessary quantum operations.  You may purchase quantum devices that come with a classical interface.  However, you may not necessarily trust the manufacturer's claim on the inner-working of the devices.  Even if you do, the devices may be corrupted for many reasons.  An important question thus arises: what can we do through classically interacting with quantum devices that may deviate from the ideal specification? 

To address this question, the researchers are developing a theory of untrusted quantum devices through this project. Such a theory would be supported by two pillars:
(a) Robust self-testing of quantum states and quantum operations.  That is, methods for pinning down the quantum device (its state and measurements) through classical interactions.
(b) General principles for proving cryptographic properties of untrusted quantum devices.

A successful theory will identify the power and limitations of classical interactions with quantum devices.  In particular, it may provide new tools for designing and analyzing the security of cryptographic protocols that rely on untrusted quantum devices.  This will bring the tremendous potential of quantum information processing closer to reality.  The project also serves as a training program for both undergraduate and graduate students for cutting-edge research on quantum information processing.

por.por_cntn:
Quantum information enables exciting capabilities for information processing. On the other hand, quantum systems are extremely fragile, making it challenging to unleash their extraordinary power. How would a user of quantum devices be certain that the devices are performing according to specification? How would a cautious user prevent the quantum devices from undermining information security? These are fundamental questions addressed by this project.

The questions were investigated for a more specific set of tasks of generating randomness that is provably secure against quantum adversaries. Randomness is the mother secret of cryptography. Thus its secure generation is a foundational primitive for information security. All current solutions require the user to trust the generating devices. Quantum mechanics provides a new solution space where the trust on the devices can be removed. This is accomplish through certain "quantumness tests". The only way of passing such tests is to be quantum mechanical, and the latter will imply certain output being random to all external parties. 

The project has been successful in accomplishing its initial major goals: the team has provided the first security proof for such "device-independent" method for generating randomness when using quantum devices that are not perfect (as all realistic devices are), and when only a single weak randomness source is available. In the later stage of the project, the team expanded the scope of their inquiry toward the directions of obtaining stronger security guarantees under weaker assumptions. A highlight of these efforts is the first security proof of generating randomness using a single and general weak random source against a general "non-signaling" adversary (which is more powerful than quantum adversaries). This result the following implication on fundamental physics: that almost perfect randomness in principle can exist in Nature, as long as there is randomness at all.
